opinion.syllabus: 1. ARREST — Warrant — Opportunity to Obtain — Statute. When an adequate opportunity to obtain an arrest warrant exists, the police, by terms of the statute (section 16-3-102(1)(c), C.R.S. 1973), must obtain a warrant.

2. Warrantless — Items — Observed and Seized — Unlawful — Evidence. On motion to suppress, evidence supported findings of district court that items of evidence were unlawfully observed and seized during a warrantless arrest and search of defendant.

opinion.opinion_byline: MR. JUSTICE HODGES delivered the opinion of the Court.
opinion.opinion_text:
This is an interlocutory appeal by the People from a district court ruling, which ordered the suppression of evidence seized from the defendant, Mary Ann Hernandez. After a hearing on the defendant's motion to suppress, the district court made findings that the involved items of evidence were unlawfully observed and seized during a warrantless arrestPage 555 and search of this defendant and accordingly ordered the suppression of this evidence.
[1] The plain view doctrine and rule of Stone v. People, 174 Colo. 504,485 P.2d 495 (1971), as contended for by the People have no applicability under the facts of this case. When an adequate opportunity to obtain an arrest warrant exists, as it did here, the police, by the terms of section16-3-102(1)(c), C.R.S. 1973 must obtain a warrant. People v. Hoinville,191 Colo. 357, 553 P.2d 777.
[2] The findings of the district court are supported by the evidence and we therefore affirm its suppression ruling.
